content.text: Once upon a time, in a kingdom far, far away, there lived a king who was very ill.
None of the doctors or wise men in the land could cure him, and the king grew weaker with each passing day.
His three sons were filled with sorrow, for they loved their father dearly.
One evening, as the eldest prince sat by the king’s bedside, an old man appeared at the door.
He was dressed in a long, tattered cloak, and his eyes sparkled with wisdom.
“Your Majesty,” the old man said, bowing low, “I have heard of your illness.
There is but one thing that can save you—the Water of Life.
It flows from a magical spring hidden deep within a dark and dangerous forest.
Whoever drinks from it shall be healed of all ailments.”  The eldest prince, eager to save his father, stood up at once.
“I shall go and fetch the Water of Life!” he declared. The old man nodded. “Very well.
But beware—the path is treacherous, and only the pure of heart may find the spring.
Take this silver key, for it will open the gate that guards the Water of Life.
And remember, you must return before the clock strikes midnight on the third day, or the gate will vanish forever.”  The eldest prince took the key and set off at dawn.
He rode through dense forests, crossed rushing rivers, and climbed steep mountains.
But as he journeyed deeper into the woods, he grew proud and boastful. “I am the eldest,” he thought.
“I shall be the one to save our kingdom.
No one else is brave enough!”  At last, he came to a dark and twisted forest where the trees seemed to whisper warnings.
A great iron gate stood before him, covered in vines and rust.
He took out the silver key and unlocked it.
Beyond the gate lay a narrow path, lined with thorns and shadows.
The prince hesitated, for the air was cold and filled with strange sounds.
But his pride would not let him turn back. He pressed on, his heart pounding.
Suddenly, a deep voice rumbled from the darkness.

“Who dares to seek the Water of Life?”  The prince, trembling, answered, “I am the eldest son of the king, and I have come to save my father!”  A great lion stepped into the path, its golden mane shimmering in the dim light.
“Prove your worth,” the lion said. “If your heart is true, you may pass.
If not, you shall be lost forever.”  The prince, though frightened, stood tall. “I am the eldest!
I am the bravest! Let me pass!”  The lion roared, and the ground shook.
The prince turned and fled, dropping the silver key in his haste.
He ran until he could run no more, and when he finally stopped, he realized he was lost.
The forest seemed to close in around him, and he knew he would never find his way home.
---  Meanwhile, the second prince, seeing his brother had not returned, decided to take up the quest.
“I am just as brave as he is,” he said to himself.
“I shall bring back the Water of Life and save our father!”  He too received the silver key from the old man and set off on the same path.
Like his brother, he faced many dangers—wild beasts, treacherous swamps, and howling winds. But he, too, grew proud.
“I am the cleverest of the princes,” he thought.
“I shall succeed where my brother failed!”  When he reached the iron gate, he unlocked it with the key and stepped inside.
The path was just as dark and foreboding as before. Again, the lion appeared.
“Who dares to seek the Water of Life?” the lion demanded.
“I am the second son of the king,” the prince replied, “and I have come to save my father!”  “Prove your worth,” the lion said.
“If your heart is true, you may pass.
If not, you shall be lost forever.”  The prince, though nervous, puffed out his chest. “I am the cleverest!
I am the strongest! Let me pass!”  The lion roared, and the prince, like his brother, turned and fled.
He too dropped the silver key and became lost in the forest, wandering in circles until he could go no farther.
---  Now, only the youngest prince remained. He was kind and gentle, not proud like his brothers.
When he saw that neither of them had returned, he went to his father’s bedside and knelt beside him.
“Father,” he said softly, “I shall go and find the Water of Life.
I will not fail you.”  The king, though weak, placed a trembling hand on his son’s head.
“My dear child,” he whispered, “you are too young.
The journey is too dangerous.”  But the youngest prince would not be swayed.
He went to the old man and received the silver key.
“I shall bring back the Water of Life,” he promised.
The old man looked into the prince’s eyes and saw his kindness. “Go then,” he said.
“But remember—only the pure of heart may find the spring.”  The youngest prince set off, riding through the same forests and mountains as his brothers.
But unlike them, he did not boast or grow proud.
Instead, he helped those he met along the way—a lost fox, a wounded bird, and an old woman struggling to carry her firewood.
Each time, he stopped to lend a hand, and each time, the creatures thanked him with kindness in return.
When he reached the dark forest, he too found the iron gate.
He unlocked it with the silver key and stepped inside.
The path was just as frightening as before, but the prince did not hesitate.
He walked forward, his heart steady. The lion appeared once more.
“Who dares to seek the Water of Life?” it asked.
“I am the youngest son of the king,” the prince replied, “and I have come to save my father.”  “Prove your worth,” the lion said.
The prince bowed his head.
“I do not ask to pass because I am the bravest or the cleverest,” he said.
“I ask because I love my father, and I wish to help him.”  The lion studied him for a long moment, then stepped aside.
“Your heart is true,” it said.
“You may pass.”  The prince walked deeper into the forest until he came to a clearing.
There, in the center, stood a crystal spring, its waters shimmering with golden light.
Beside it lay a silver cup.
The prince filled the cup with the Water of Life and turned to leave.
But as he did, he noticed two figures lying in the shadows—his brothers!
They had been turned to stone by the lion’s magic for their pride. The prince’s heart ached for them.
He knelt beside them and sprinkled a few drops of the Water of Life onto their stone forms.
At once, they began to change, their bodies warming and softening until they were flesh and blood once more.
“Brothers!” the youngest prince cried. “You are alive!”  The eldest and second princes looked around in confusion.
“How did we get here?” the eldest asked. “You were turned to stone,” the youngest prince explained.
“But the Water of Life has saved you.”  The brothers hung their heads in shame.
“We were foolish,” the second prince said. “We thought only of ourselves.”  The youngest prince smiled.
“There is time to make amends.
Let us return home together.”  The three princes hurried back through the forest, the youngest carrying the silver cup filled with the Water of Life.
They reached the iron gate just as the clock struck midnight on the third day.
The gate creaked shut behind them, and the path vanished into mist.
When they returned to the castle, the youngest prince rushed to his father’s bedside.
The king drank the Water of Life, and at once, his strength returned.
His cheeks grew rosy, his eyes bright, and he sat up with a joyful cry. “My son!” he exclaimed.
“You have saved me!”  The kingdom rejoiced, and the king held a great feast in honor of his youngest son.
The eldest and second princes, humbled by their journey, asked for their father’s forgiveness.
The king, seeing their change of heart, embraced them all.
And so, the kingdom lived in peace and happiness, all because the youngest prince had a kind and loving heart.
And from that day forward, whenever someone spoke of bravery, they did not speak of strength or cunning, but of kindness and love.
